moves.1. e4: A brilliant game ! I try to anotate although I do not have the level.
moves.4. d4 Nc6 5. Nf3 Bf5: Probably to avoid 6.Bd3, for black doesn't want to play c4
moves.6. Be3 Nf6 7. Nbd2: Enabling 8. Bc4 but closing the d file for the queen. Would Na3 have been better ?
moves.7... cxd4 8. Bc4: The black queen has little place to go and there is a danger for black on f7.
moves.8... dxe3:
Queen sacrifice !?
The computer doesn't consider it as a mistake, so that it has to be !!
moves.9... exd2+ 10. Qxd2: If 10. Nxd2 Nxd2 and material value is equal but black is better in developpement
moves.12. Qf4: Unpinning the bishop and menacing to exchange bishops if black plays 13... exd5
moves.12... Bb4+: Just to prevent black to castle
moves.13... Bd6: Black wants to send the white queen away from the LSB to take on d5
moves.14. Qg5: Only move to carry on menacing the LSB
moves.16. Qxf7:
Critical point of the game :
White has a strong material advance (partly compensated by the fact that white will take the LSB)
Black's pawn structure is terrible
but :
White will quickly be out of the center
The white king is extremely weak
Black pieces are more active and better connected ( The white queen is alone and in danger)
Black has a rook on the central open file.
moves.16... Nf4+ 17. Kd1: White has little other choice (because of black's bishops)
moves.18... exd5: Finally black takes the bishop and is evidently better now because white's rooks are blocked.
moves.19. c5: White needs to keep the d5 pawn on the d file to block black's d rook
moves.19... Bc7: I had trouble to understand this move (19... Bxc5 is so tempting and evident). Black probably wants to avoid the pin of his c knight by the a rook)
moves.21... Nxg2: Not taking with the rook, for this menaces fork attack by a further Bf4
moves.22. h3: To prevent 22... Bg4 pinning the knight.
moves.22... Bg6: Again a move that I have had trouble to understand but for white 23. Rg1 is not possible fr the white queen would be trapped (23... Bf4 and the queen has no escape)
moves.23. Qd2: Only safe place for the queen (23.g4 means death because of 23... Bc2+)
moves.23... Bf4: Is this move, the reason of19... Bc7, 4 moves ago ?
moves.24. Qc3: alternative move was :24. Qe2 but it would allow 24... Re8
moves.24... d4: Blak carries on harassing the queen instead of taking the c rook
moves.25. Qb3: I was asking myself why not Qc4.
moves.25... Bh5: Now I can see why the white queen is better on the 3rd line.
moves.26. Kc2: Not sure about this move. It joins the rooks and white is planning to hide in b1 but masks the c rook and enable black's next move.
moves.28... Kb8 29. Ne5: Only place to save the knight.
moves.31... d2 32. Qb5+: White is playing for the draw.
moves.32... Kc7: If black stays on the 8th line, he is facing perpetual chess
moves.33. Qa5+ Kc8 34. Qa6+ Kd7 35. Qa4+: If white takes the a pawn (35. Qxa7+, black plays 35... Ke8 and the game is over.)
moves.35... Ke6:
Why not 35... Ke7 ?
Probably because if 35... Ke7 36.Qe4 Be5 and white has a chance to give perpetual chess...
moves.36. Rd1: White sees that he cannot give perpetual chess so that he has to block the pawn.
moves.36... Bxd1 37. Qxd1 Ne1 38. c6: What a brilliant game ! I've learned a lot, trying to anotate it. Thanks to both players
